fields.value: Red Blood Cell aggregates in a dynamic flow

dsDescriptionValue.value: Red Blood Cell aggregates flowing dynamically in a two fluid flow shearing system suspended at 5, 10 and 15% hematocrit (H), at different flow rates (Q=35, 20, 10, 7.5, 5 µL/hr). The data are shown for two different samples (#6 and #11) at two different temperatures, T=23°C and T=37°C, respectively. The videos show the detected and labeled aggregates based on their respective sizes under different conditions. Original recordings of the flow are also provided for sample #11 at 5% hematocrit.

publicationCitation.value: Mehri R, Niazi E, Mavriplis C, Fenech M. An automatic method for dynamic Red Blood Cell aggregate detection in microfluidic flow. Physiol Meas. 2017; Accepted Manuscript

files.description: Processed human RBC aggregates (Sample #6) suspended in their autologous plasma at 10% hematocrit flowing at 10 µL/hr under a controlled shear rate of 5.7 s-1. Acquisition was done at 20X magnification (0.27 µm/pixel) at 160 frames per seconds, while processing was done on 60 frames at 8 frames per seconds. The video displays these frames at 10 frames per seconds (6 seconds video). The color coding of the aggregates detected was done based on their respective sizes: The blue, green and red RBC aggregates correspond to sizes of < 100 µm2, 100-360 µm2 and > 360 µm2, respectively.
files.label: 10H_Q10_6.avi

dataFile.description: Processed human RBC aggregates (Sample #6) suspended in their autologous plasma at 10% hematocrit flowing at 10 µL/hr under a controlled shear rate of 5.7 s-1. Acquisition was done at 20X magnification (0.27 µm/pixel) at 160 frames per seconds, while processing was done on 60 frames at 8 frames per seconds. The video displays these frames at 10 frames per seconds (6 seconds video). The color coding of the aggregates detected was done based on their respective sizes: The blue, green and red RBC aggregates correspond to sizes of < 100 µm2, 100-360 µm2 and > 360 µm2, respectively.

files.description: Processed human RBC aggregates (Sample #11) suspended in their autologous plasma at 10% hematocrit flowing at 10 µL/hr under a controlled shear rate of 15.7 s-1. Acquisition was done at 20X magnification (0.27 µm/pixel) at 160 frames per seconds, while processing was done on 60 frames at 8 frames per seconds. The video displays these frames at 5 frames per seconds (12 seconds video). The color coding of the aggregates detected was done based on their respective sizes and is detailed in Mehri et al. 2017 (Physiol Meas. 2017, doi:10.1088/1361-6579/aaa0ad).

The color coding of the aggregates detected was done based on their respective sizes and is detailed in Mehri et al. 2017 (Physiol Meas. 2017, doi:10.1088/1361-6579/aaa0ad).

files.description: Original human RBC aggregates (Sample #11) suspended in their autologous plasma at 5% hematocrit flowing at 10 µL/hr under a controlled shear rate of 4.6 s-1. The entire microchannel is shown for this video where the entraining layer (top layer) can be seen. Acquisition was done at 20X magnification (0.27 µm/pixel) at 160 frames per seconds. However, processing was done at 8 frames per seconds. The video displays these frames at 5 frames per seconds (12 seconds video).
